physDesc.p: This letter is 2 pages long (seq. 38-39). It is typed on notebook paper that has tears around the edge. The words “John Gould” are written in pencil across the top of the first page.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I am very glad indeed to know that you are arriving in our town, although I confess I wish you had not done so quite so hastily, and had looked over the ground a little bit before you came. I say this purely on your own account, for the ground does not lie quite so well as it will three weeks later. By which I mean that Mr. Engel had an operation yesterday, and is in hospital, and I do not suppose he will be back at his office for three weeks. Under these circumstances, of course, he cannot give you any job to do before that time at least, or so I should imagine. Also I am working night and day on these proofs; and in the few moments after dinner in which I am not hard at work I am a very dull person I am afraid, as the fatigue attendant on so long a stretch of drudgery has almost floored me. However, we will do our best, and I hope that Ferris Greenslet will be able to find you something pending Mr. Engel's recovery.

Please telephone me when you reach town, or as soon after you get placed as possible, just to let me give you the glad hand and "welcome to our city." I am afraid there is no use in suggesting that you come out here before Sunday, as I shall really have not a moment to spare. The motor goes back and forth to Norwood where the press is with copy twice a day, and it leaves me absolutely filled up. My miserable health this summer has delayed the thing a month, and the publishersare impatient and so am I.

I shall expect you on Sunday to supper at seven as usual, and we will take up our old routine and have as pleasant a talk as last year. In the meantime, here is the twenty-five dollars, which you may return or not on the first of December, as you please.
